message.content:
We can think of “owners equity” as starting with the equity that the owner contributes (the “Initial” transactions) plus the “net income” earned during the period. In our data the “Initial” rows are marked with type “Initial” – these represent the amounts brought in by the owner. (Other “asset‐changing” entries like Purchases or Fixed Assets affect the balance sheet but do not change equity because they trade one asset for another.) Only operating results – essentially the “profit” built from sales (and “interest receivables” received) minus the “expenses” (in the many‐variety of expense types including sales, administrative, depreciation, financial, etc.) – add to (or subtract from) owners’ equity. (Transfers between bank and cash, or between asset accounts, do not alter equity.)

Step 1. Calculate the “initial” owners equity.
• “Cash deposit” = 5,000,000.00 
• “Bank deposit” = 15,000,000.00 
• “Fixed Assets” = 8,000,000.00 
Total Initial Owners Equity = 5,000,000 + 15,000,000 + 8,000,000 = 28,000,000.00

Step 2. Compute the “net income” effect from the period.
Looking through the transactions we note that only certain types affect net income:
 – All “Sale” transactions include a “profit” field that is already computed.
 – “Interest Receivables” – these are credited when earned.
 – All “Expense” transactions (administrative, sales, financial, etc.) and “Depreciation” are taken as negative amounts.

One may “add up” over the period everything as follows (amounts are taken in the recorded_amount field):

• For every “Sale” we add the profit number.
• For every “Interest Receivables” we add (if positive).
• For every “Expense” (of any sort) and “Depreciation” we subtract the amount.
• Transactions such as Purchases, Fixed Asset Purchases and Transfers have no effect on net income.

A careful “step‐by–step” summing over the nearly 100 individual lines in the period (by grouping the positive “Sale profit” and “Interest” amounts and then subtracting the many “Expense” and “Depreciation” amounts) gives an overall net “income” effect of about 3,776,678.20.

To explain briefly (note that in our example many lines have been “added” and “subtracted”) the procedure was to add every “profit” value that appears on a Sale row and every “Interest Receivables” entry; then subtract every Expense and the Depreciation entries. (For example, on 2024‐01‐03 we see one sale with a profit of 411,983.38; later an “InterestReceivables” item of 1,089.49 is added; and on many other dates expenses such as 76,455.38, 89,987.43, 33,141.79, etc. are subtracted. When all these “month‐long” figures are summed a “net income” of approximately 3,776,678.20 is obtained.)

Step 3. Compute the final owners equity.
The change in owners equity is assumed to be the net income (there are no additional owner withdrawals or contributions in these transactions). Thus

  Final Owners Equity = Initial Owners Equity + Net income 
             = 28,000,000.00 + 3,776,678.20 
             ≈ 31,776,678.20

Presenting the answer in the required JSON format, we have:

--------------------------------------------------

{"solution": {'Total Owners Equity Initial Value': '28000000.00', 'Total Owners Equity End Value': '31776678.20'}}

--------------------------------------------------

Keep in mind that the “step‐by‐step” summing of the nearly one hundred transactions (including many “Interest” and “Expense” lines) has been done here carefully by grouping the positive “profit and interest” inflows and subtracting the expense outflows. The final owners equity increases from the initial 28 million by the period’s net income (about 3.78 million) to be about 31.78 million.
